Text: For the choirmaster. To Jeduthun. A Psalm of David.
Context: This introductory verse sets the stage for the Psalm, indicating it is a musical piece intended for the leader of the choir and possibly to be played with the accompaniment of Jeduthun, who was known for leading music in David’s time.

Text: My soul finds rest in God alone; my salvation comes from Him.
Context: The psalmist expresses a serene trust in God as the sole source of salvation and rest for his soul, indicating a sense of peace and reliance.

Text: He alone is my rock and my salvation; He is my fortress, I will never be shaken.
Context: The psalmist conveys a strong confidence in God‘s ability to protect and sustain him, comparing God to a rock and fortress that offers unshakable security.

Text: How long will you assault a man? Would all of you throw him down—this leaning wall, this tottering fence?
Context: This verse reflects the psalmist’s feeling of being under attack by others, using the metaphor of a weak structure to describe his precarious situation.

Text: They fully intend to topple him from his place of honor; they delight in lies; they bless with their mouths, but inwardly they curse. Selah
Context: The psalmist describes the malicious intent of his adversaries who seek to destroy his honor and use deceit, highlighting the discrepancy between their words and their hearts.

Text: Find rest, O my soul, in God alone; my hope comes from Him.
Context: The psalmist speaks to his own soul, encouraging it to find rest and hope in God, re-emphasizing the theme of trust and reliance.

Text: He alone is my rock and my salvation; He is my fortress, I will not be shaken.
Context: Repeating the sentiment from verse 2, the psalmist reinforces his unwavering faith in God‘s protection and the stability it provides.

Text: My salvation and my honor depend on God; He is my mighty rock, my refuge.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges that both his deliverance and his dignity are tied to God, elaborating further on the metaphor of God as a strong and protective refuge.

Text: Trust in Him at all times, O people; pour out your hearts before Him. God is a refuge for us. Selah
Context: The psalmist expands the call to trust in God to all people, encouraging a candid pouring out of the heart to God who serves as a shelter for everyone.

Text: Lowborn men are but a breath, the highborn are but a lie; if weighed on a balance, they are nothing; together they are only a breath.
Context: The psalmist provides a perspective on the fleeting and insubstantial nature of humanity, regardless of social status, emphasizing the transient nature of human life and power.

Text: Do not trust in extortion or take false hope in stolen goods; though your riches increase, do not set your heart on them.
Context: The psalmist warns against placing trust in ill-gotten gains and the uncertainty of wealth, advising not to become attached to material possessions.

Text: One thing God has spoken, two things I have heard: that You, O God, are strong,
Context: Reflecting on what he has learned from God’s word, the psalmist focuses on God‘s strength, possibly indicating a contrast with the preceding examination of human frailty.

Text: and that You, O Lord, are loving. Surely You will repay each person according to what he has done.
Context: The psalmist recognizes God’s loving nature and the assurance of divine justice, where everyone will be rewarded or punished according to their actions.
